page.title: List of Superfund sites in Arizona

revision.text:
[[Image:Superfund sites in Arizona.svg|thumb|right|alt=Outline of map of Oregon with colored dots representing the location of Superfund sites in the state|A map of superfund sites in Arizona.]] This is a '''list of Superfund sites in Arizona''' designated under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) environmental law. The CERCLA federal law of 1980 authorized the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to create a list of [[Pollution|polluted]] locations requiring a long-term response to clean up hazardous material contaminations.P.L. 96-510, {{USC|42|9601|9675}}), December 11, 1980. These locations are known as [[Superfund]] sites, and are placed on the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL). The NPL guides the EPA in "determining which sites warrant further investigation" for [[environmental remediation]]. As of May 1, 2010, there were nine Superfund sites on the National Priorities List in [[Arizona]].{{cite web| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/ |title=National Priorities List |publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Three other sites have been cleaned up and removed from it; no sites are currently proposed for addition to the NPL. ==Superfund sites== :{{legend2|#d0f0c0|Deleted from National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#ffffff|Not on National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !CERCLIS ID !Name !County !Reason !Proposed !Listed{{cite web|title=Final NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplfin.htm| accessdate=2010-05-01}} !Construction
completed{{cite web|title=Construction Completions at NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplccl.htm| accessdate=2010-05-01}} !Partially
deleted{{cite web|title=Partial deletions at NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplpdel.htm| accessdate=2010-05-01}} !Deleted{{cite web|title=Deleted NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/npldel.htm| accessdate=2010-05-01}} |-style="background:#ffffff" ||AZD980695969||[[Abandoned Uranium Mines]]||[[Navajo Nation]]||Physical hazards and [[uranium]] contamination from 520 abandoned uranium mines.{{cite web| title=Abandoned Uranium Mines on the Navajo Nation |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Abandoned+Uranium+Mines+On+The+Navajo+Nation?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||{{center|–}} ||{{center|–}} ||{{center|–}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZD008399263||[[Apache Powder Company]]||[[Cochise County, Arizona|Cochise]]||Groundwater contaminated with [[arsenic]], [[fluoride]], [[nitrate]], and [[perchlorate]]. Soil contaminated with [[arsenic]], [[antimony]], [[barium]], [[beryllium]], [[chromium]], [[lead]], [[manganese]], nitrate, [[2,4-Dinitrotoluene|2,4-DNT]], [[2,6-Dinitrotoluene|2,6-DNT]], lead, [[Vanadium(V) oxide|vanadium pentoxide]], [[hydrocarbons|paraffin]]s, and [[Trinitrotoluene|TNT]] from the commercial production of chemicals.{{cite web| title=Apache Powder Company site description |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/ViewByEPAID/azd008399263?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-01-10}}{{cite web| title=Apache Powder Company NPL site narrative |url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/nar1704.htm |accessdate=2010-01-10}}{{cite web | title=Apache Powder Company Superfund site progress profile | url=http://cfpub.epa.gov/supercpad/cursites/csitinfo.cfm?id=0900510 | accessdate=2010-01-10 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616182603/http://cfpub.epa.gov/supercpad/cursites/csitinfo.cfm?id=0900510 | archivedate=2011-06-16 | df= }}||06/10/1986 ||08/30/1990 ||{{center|09/26/2008}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZD980735666||[[Hassayampa Landfill]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Groundwater contamination by [[VOCs]] including [[haloalkanes]], [[alkyl halides]] and [[toluene]], from landfilling of hazardous waste. Soil contamination by [[VOCs]], [[heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metals]], [[pesticide]]s and [[Lime (material)|lime]] wastes.{{cite web| title=Hassayampa Landfill |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/ViewByEPAID/azd980735666?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||06/10/1986 ||07/22/1987 ||{{center|09/30/1997}} || {{center|–}}|| {{center|–}} |- ||AZD980695969||[[Indian Bend Wash Area]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Groundwater contamination (and isolated soil contamination) by [[VOCs]] including [[trichloroethylene|TCE]] and [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]] from former industrial disposal practices.{{cite web| title=North Indian Bend Wash Area |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/North+Indian+Bend+Wash+Superfund+Site?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}}{{cite web| title=South Indian Bend Wash Area |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/South+Indian+Bend+Wash+Area?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||12/30/1982 ||09/08/1983 ||{{center|09/28/2006}} || {{center|05/01/2003}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZ0000309013||[[Iron King Mine - Humboldt Smelter]]||[[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai]]||[[Arsenic]] contamination of soil, sediments, surface water and ground water, including several private wells and one municipal well. Arsenic and [[lead]] contamination of soil in residential yards.{{cite web| title=Iron King Mine - Humboldt Smelter |publisher=EPA |url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/nar1779.htm |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||03/19/2008 ||09/03/2008 || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}}|| {{center|–}} |-style="background:#d0f0c0" ||AZ0570024133||[[Luke Air Force Base]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Soil and potential groundwater contamination with waste oils and [[VOCs]] from base operations.{{cite web| title=Luke Air Force Base |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Luke+Air+Force+Base?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||07/14/1989 ||08/30/1990||{{center|09/25/2000}} || {{center|–}} ||{{center|04/22/2002}} |- ||AZD009004177||[[Motorola, Inc. (52nd Street Plant)]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Soil and groundwater contamination by various chlorinated hydrocarbons used as solvents.{{cite web| title=Motorola, Inc. (52nd Street Plant) |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/ViewByEPAID/AZD009004177?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||10/15/1984 ||10/04/1989 || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |-style="background:#d0f0c0" ||AZD980735724||[[Mountain View Mobile Home Estates]]||[[Gila County, Arizona|Gila]]||[[Asbestos]] contamination of soil and air from asbestos milling operations.{{cite web| title=Mountain View Mobile Home Estates |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/ViewByEPAID/AZD980735724?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||12/30/1982 ||09/08/1983 ||{{center|04/18/1988}} || {{center|–}} ||{{center|04/18/1988}} |-style="background:#d0f0c0" ||AZD980496780||[[Nineteenth Avenue Landfill]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Landfill site, containing some hazardous waste, was at risk from leaching, river erosion and flooding. Low-level groundwater contamination.{{cite web| title=Nineteenth Avenue Landfill |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Nineteenth+Avenue+Landfill?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||12/30/1982 ||09/08/1983 ||{{center|02/17/1998}} || {{center|–}} ||{{center|09/25/2006}} |- ||AZD980695902||[[Phoenix Goodyear Airport|Phoenix-Goodyear Airport Area]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Groundwater contamination by [[chromium]], solvents, [[trichloroethylene|TCE]] and other [[VOCs]].{{cite web| title=Phoenix-Goodyear Airport Area |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Phoenix-Goodyear+Airport+Area?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||12/30/1982 ||09/08/1983 || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZD980737530||[[Tucson International Airport|Tucson International Airport Area]]||[[Pima County, Arizona|Pima]]||Groundwater contamination by [[trichloroethylene|TCE]] and some other substances.{{cite web| title=Tucson International Airport Area |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Tucson+International+Airport+Area?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||12/30/1982 ||09/08/1983 || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZ7570028582||[[Williams Air Force Base]]||[[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa]]||Groundwater contamination by [[light non-aqueous phase liquid]]s and [[VOCs]]; soil contaminated by [[VOCs]], [[PCBs]] and [[pesticides]] from past disposal practices.{{cite web| title=Williams Air Force Base |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/ViewByEPAID/AZ7570028582?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||07/14/1989 ||11/21/1989 || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- ||AZ0971590062||[[Marine Corps Air Station Yuma|Yuma Marine Corps Air Station]]||[[Yuma County, Arizona|Yuma]]||Asbestos soil contamination and groundwater contamination by [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]], [[trichloroethylene|TCE]] and [[dichloroethylene|DCE]].{{cite web| title=Yuma Marine Air Corps Station |publisher=EPA |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/r9/sfund/r9sfdocw.nsf/vwsoalphabetic/Yuma+Marine+Corps+Air+Station?OpenDocument |accessdate=2010-05-01}} ||06/24/1988 ||02/21/1990 ||{{center|09/20/2000}} || {{center|–}} || {{center|–}} |- |} ==See also== *[[List of Superfund sites in the United States]] *[[List of environmental issues]] *[[List of waste types]] *[[TOXMAP]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplfin.htm#AZ EPA list of current Superfund sites in Arizona] *[http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplprop.htm#AZ EPA list of proposed Superfund sites in Arizona] *[http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplccl.htm#AZ EPA list of Superfund site construction completions in Arizona] *[http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplpdel.htm#AZ EPA list of partially deleted Superfund sites in Arizona] *[http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/npldel.htm#AZ EPA list of deleted Superfund sites in Arizona] {{Superfund sites in the United States}} {{Arizona}} [[Category:Superfund sites in Arizona| ]] [[Category:Lists of places in Arizona|Superfund]] [[Category:Lists of Superfund sites in the United States|Arizona]] [[Category:Arizona-related lists|Superfund]]

revision.text:
{{See also|List of bilateral animal orders}} {{refimprove |date=September 2014}} The following is a list of the [[class (biology)|classes]] in each [[phylum]] of the kingdom [[Animal]]ia. There are 107 classes of animals in 33 phyla in this list. However, different sources give different numbers of classes and phyla. For e.g, [[Protura]], [[Diplura]], and [[Collembola]] are often considered to be the three orders in the class [[Entognatha]]. This list should by no means be considered complete and authoritative and should be used carefully. {{TOC right}}
==[[Incertae sedis|Unknown phylum]]== *[[Micrognathozoa]]
==[[Acanthocephala]] (thorny-headed worms)== *[[Archiacanthocephala]] *[[Eoacanthocephala]] *[[Palaeacanthocephala]] (ancient thornheads)
==[[Acoelomorpha]] (simple soft-bodied flatworms)== *[[Acoela]] *[[Nemertodermatida]]
==[[Annelida]] (segmented worms)==
*[[Aelosomata]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ramel|first1=Gordon|title=The Annelids (Phylum Annelida)|url=https://www.earthlife.net/inverts/annelida.html|website=www.earthlife.net}}</ref> *[[Clitellata]] (earthworms) *[[Myzostomida]] *[[Polychaeta]] (bristle worms) *[[Echiura]] (spoon worms) *[[Sipuncula]] (peanut worms)
==[[Arthropoda]] (arthropods: insects, crustaceans, arachnids, centipedes, and millipedes)== {{see also|List of arthropod orders}}
===[[Chelicerata]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Integrated Taxonomic Information System|title=ITIS Standard Report Page: Chelicerata|url=https://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=82697#|website=www.itis.gov}}</ref>=== *[[Arachnida]] (spiders, scorpions, and kin) *[[Xiphosura]] (horseshoe crabs; only 4 [[Extant taxon|extant]] species) *[[Pycnogonida]] (sea spiders)
===[[Crustacean|Crustacea]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Integrated Taxonomic Information System|title=ITIS Standard Report Page: Crustacea|url=https://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=83677#null|website=www.itis.gov}}</ref>=== *[[Branchiopoda]] (fairy shrimp, tadpole shrimp, water fleas, and clam shrimp)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Regents of the University of California|title=Introduction to Brachiopoda|url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/arthropoda/crustacea/branchiopoda.html|website=www.ucmp.berkeley.edu}}</ref> *[[Cephalocarida]] (horseshoe shrimp; only 12 described species)<ref>https://www.uni-ulm.de/fileadmin/website_uni_ulm/nawi.biodok/publikationen/2011_Olesen_etal_Cephalocarida-k.pdf</ref> *[[Malacostraca]] (crabs, lobsters, crayfish, krill, various shrimp, woodlice, and kin)f<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conlan|first1=Kathleen E.|last2=Bousfield|first2=Edward|title=Malacostracan <nowiki>|</nowiki> crustacean|url=https://www.britannica.com/animal/malacostracan|website=www.britannica.com}}</ref> *[[Maxillopoda]] (barnacles, copepods, fish lice, and other groups)<ref>http://atiniui.nhm.org/pdfs/3839/3839.pdf</ref> *[[Ostracoda]] (seed shrimp)<ref>http://atiniui.nhm.org/pdfs/3839/3839.pdf</ref> *[[Remipedia]]
===[[Hexapoda]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ITIS Standard Report Page: Hexapoda|url=https://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=563886#null|website=www.itis.gov|publisher=Integrated Taxonomic Information System}}</ref>=== *[[Entognatha]] (coneheads, two-pronged bristletails and springtails) *[[Insect]]a (insects)
===[[Myriapoda]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ITIS Standard Report Page: Myriapoda|url=https://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=563885#null|website=www.itis.gov|publisher=Integrated Taxonomic Information System}}</ref>=== *[[Chilopoda]] (centipedes) *[[Diplopoda]] (millipedes) *[[Pauropoda]] *[[Symphyla]] (pseudocentipedes)
==[[Brachiopoda]] ("lamp shells")== *[[Craniforma]] *[[Lingulata]] *[[Rhynchonellata]]
==[[Bryozoa]] (moss animals)== *[[Gymnolaemata]] *[[Phylactolaemata]] *[[Stenolaemata]]
==[[Chaetognatha]] (arrow worms)== *[[Archisagittoidea]] *[[Sagittoidea]]
==[[Chordate|Chordata]] (vertebrates, tunicates, and lancelets)== {{see also|List of chordate orders}}
===[[Cephalochordata]]=== *[[Leptocardii]] (lancelet)
===[[Tunicata]]=== *[[Appendicularia]] (larvaceans) *[[Ascidiacea]] (sea squirts) *[[Sorberacea]] *[[Thaliacea]] (salps, pyrosomes, and doliolids)
===[[Vertebrata]]===
====[[Agnatha]]====
=====[[Cyclostomata]]===== *[[Myxini]] (hagfish) *[[Petromyzontida]] (lampraey)
====[[Gnathostomata]]====
*[[Chondrichthyes]] (cartilaginous fish, mostly sharks and rays)
=====[[Tetrapoda]]===== * [[Amphibia]] (amphibians) * [[Amniota]] ** [[Mammalia]] (mammals) ** [[Aves]] (birds) ** [[Reptilia]] (reptiles)
=====[[Osteichthyes]]===== *[[Actinopterygii]] (ray-finned fish, which includes most familiar bony fish) *[[Sarcopterygii]] (lobe-finned fish)
==[[Cnidaria]] (marine stinging animals)== *[[Anthozoa]] (anemones and corals) *[[Cubozoa]] (box jellyfish) *[[Hydrozoa]] (hydroids) *[[Malacosporea]] (marine parasites) *[[Myxosporea]] (marine parasites) *[[Scyphozoa]] (true jellyfish) *[[Staurozoa]] (stalked jellyfish) *[[Polypodiozoa]] (marine parasites)
==[[Cycliophora]] (tiny marine animals)== *[[Symbion|Eucycliophora]]
==[[Dicyemida]] (rhombozoa)== *Dicyemida
==[[Echinodermata]] (starfish, sea urchins, sand dollars, sea lilies, and others)== {{see also|List of echinodermata orders}}
===[[Crinozoa]]=== *[[Crinoidea]] (sea lilies and feather stars)
===[[Asterozoa]]=== *[[Asteroidea]] (star fish) *[[Ophiuroidea]] (brittle stars)
===[[Echinozoa]]=== *[[Echinoidea]] (sea urchins) *[[Holothuroidea]] (sea cucumbers)
==[[Entoprocta]]== *Entoprocta
==[[Gastrotricha]] (hairybacks)== *Gastrotricha
==[[Gnathostomulida]] (jaw worms)== *Gnathostomulida
==[[Hemichordata]] == *[[Enteropneusta]] (acorn worms) *[[Pterobranchia]]
==[[Kinorhyncha]] (mud dragons)== *[[Kinorhyncha]]
==[[Loricifera]]== *[[Loricifera]]
==[[Mollusca]] (mollusks)== *[[Bivalvia]] (clams, mussels, scallops, and kin) *[[Caudofoveata]] *[[Cephalopoda]] (octopuses, squids and cuttlefish) *[[Gastropoda]] (snails and slugs) *[[Monoplacophora]] *[[Polyplacophora]] (chitons, or sea cradles) *[[Scaphopoda]] (tusk shells) *[[Solenogastres]]
==[[Nematoda]] (roundworms)== *[[Adenophorea]] *[[Chromadorea]] *[[Secernentea]]
==[[Nematomorpha]] (horsehair worms)== *[[Gordioidea]] *[[Nectonematoida]]
==[[Nemertea]] (ribbon worms)== *[[Anopla]] *[[Enopla]]
==[[Onychophora]] (velvet worms)== *[[Udeonychophora]]
==[[Orthonectida]]== *[[Orthonectida]]
==[[Placozoa]]== *[[Trichoplacoidea]]
==[[Platyhelminthes]] (flatworms)== *[[Cestoda]] (tapeworms and relatives) *[[Monogenea]] *[[Trematoda]] (flukes) *[[Turbellaria]] (e.g. ''[[Dugesia]]'')
==[[Porifera]] (sponges)== *[[Calcarea]] (calcareous sponges) *[[Demospongiae]] *[[Hexactinellida]] (glass sponges) *[[Homoscleromorpha]]
==[[Priapulida]] (priapulid worms)== *[[Halicryptomorpha]] *[[Priapulimorpha]] *[[Seticoronaria]]
==[[Rotifera]] (rotifers)== *[[Bdelloidea]] *[[Monogononta]] *[[Seisonidea]]
==[[Tardigrada]] (tardigrades, water bears, or moss piglets)== *[[Eutardigrada]] *[[Heterotardigrada]]
==[[Xenoturbellida]]== *[[Xenoturbellida]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:animal classes}} [[Category:Taxonomic lists]]

revision.comment: Made highlights more distinct after a review comment on a related page noted that the original very pale colours could not be distinguished very easily on some devices

revision.text:
{{merge|Kampo list|date=June 2018}}{{see also|Kampo list}} '''''Kampō''''' (or ''Kanpō'', 漢方) medicine is the [[Japan]]ese study and adaptation of [[traditional Chinese medicine]]. In 1967, the Japanese [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare]] approved four ''[[kampo]]'' medicines for reimbursement under the National Health Insurance (NHI) program. In 1976, 82 [[kampo]] medicines were approved by the [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)|Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare]]. Currently, 148 [[kampo list|''kampo'' medicines]] are approved for reimbursement. [http://www.itmonline.org/arts/kampo.htm] The 14th edition of the ''Japanese Pharmacopoeia'' (JP) (日本薬局方 Nihon yakkyokuhō) lists 165 herbal ingredients that are approved to be used in ''kampo'' remedies. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926083230/http://www.herbalgram.org/youngliving/herbclip/pdfs/041806-179.pdf] The following are the most common herbs used in it: Tsumura (ツムラ) is the leading maker;[https://web.archive.org/web/20060927141157/http://www.tsumura.co.jp/english/kampo/wik/resource.htm] they make 128 of the 148 ''kampo]] medicines. The "count" column shows in how many of these 128 formulae the herb is found. The most common herb is [[Glycyrrhiza|Glycyrrhizae Radix]] (Chinese liquorice root). It is in 94 of the 128 Tsumura formulae. Other common herbs are [[Ginger|Zingiberis Rhizoma]] (ginger) (51 of 128 formulae) and [[Paeonia lactiflora|Paeoniae Radix]] (Chinese peony root) (44 of 128 formulae). {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name ![[Common name|Common Name]] ![[Kanji]] ![[Katakana]] ![[Pinyin]] !Chinese ([[Traditional Chinese|T]]) !Chinese ([[Simplified Chinese|S]]) ![[Binomial nomenclature|Genus species]] !Count |- |Achyranthis Radix |achyranthis root |牛膝 |ゴシツ |niú xī |牛膝 |牛膝 |''[[Achyranthes fauriei]]'' |3 |- |[[Aconitum|Aconiti Rhizoma]] |Carmichael's monkshood rhizome |附子 |ブシ |fù zǐ |附子 |附子 |''[[Aconitum carmichaelii]]'' |6 |- |[[Akebia|Akebiae Caulis]] |chocolate vine stem |木通 |モクツウ |mù tōng |木通 |木通 |''[[Akebia quinata]]'' |5 |- |[[Alisma|Alismatis Rhizoma]] |water plantain rhizome |沢瀉 |タクシャ |zé xiè |澤瀉 |泽泻 |''[[Alisma orientale]]'' |14 |- |[[Galangal|Alpiniae Officinari Rhizoma]] |lesser galangal rhizome |良姜 |リョウキョウ |liáng jiāng |良薑 |良姜 |''Alpinia officinarum'' |1 |- |[[Amomum|Amomi Semen]] |black cardamom seed |縮砂 |シュクシャ |shā rén |砂仁 |砂仁 |''Amomum xanthioides'' |1 |- |Anemarrhenae Rhizoma |[[anemarrhena]] rhizome |知母 |チモ |zhī mǔ |知母 |知母 |''Anemarrhena asphodeloides'' |6 |- |[[Angelica|Angelicae Dahuricae Radix]] |angelica root |白芷 |ビャクシ |bái zhǐ |白芷 |白芷 |''Angelica dahurica'' |5 |- |[[Angelica|Angelicae Radix]] |Chinese angelica root |当帰 |トウキ |dāng guī |當歸 |当归 |''Angelica acutiloba'' |37 |- |[[Aralia cordata|Araliae Cordatae Radix]] |Japanese spikenard root |和羌活 |ワキョウカツ |tǔ dāng guī |土當歸 |土当归 |''Aralia cordata'' |1 |- |[[Aralia cordata|Araliae Cordatae Rhizoma]] |Japanese spikenard rhizome |独活 |ドッカツ |tǔ dāng guī |土當歸 |土当归 |''Aralia cordata'' |1 |- |[[Arctium lappa|Arctii Fructus]] |greater burdock fruit |牛蒡子 |ゴボウシ |niú bàng zǐ |牛蒡子 |牛蒡子 |''Arctium lappa'' |2 |- |[[Areca nut|Arecae Semen]] |betel nut

"庶" is usually substituted in Chinese and Japanese. The "灬" in "庶" should be replaced with "虫". *Note 2: this character cannot be displayed correctly on a computer. "梨" is usually substituted in Chinese. "梨" or "藜" is usually substituted in Japanese. revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/131.111.247.27|131.111.247.27]] ([[User talk:131.111.247.27|talk]]) to last revision by Jklamo. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} The following page lists all '''[[nuclear power station]]s''' that are larger than {{nowrap|1,000 [[Megawatt|MW]]}} in current net capacity. Those power stations that are smaller than {{nowrap|1,000 MW}}, and those that are only at a planning or proposal stage, may be found in regional lists at the end of the page or in the [[list of nuclear reactors]]. The list is based on figures from PRIS (Power Reactor Information System) maintained by [[International Atomic Energy Agency]].
== In service == [[File:Kashiwazaki-Kariwa cropped.jpg|thumb|200px|Aerial view of the [[Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Bruce-Nuclear-Szmurlo.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Bruce Nuclear Generating Station]]]] [[File:Kernkraftwerk Saporischschja.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Centrale nucléaire de Gravelines.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Gravelines Nuclear Power Station]]]] [[File:Nuclear Power Plant Cattenom.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Cattenom Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Hamaoka NPP 201005.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Hamaoka Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Ohi Nuclear Power Plant (02010077).jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Ōi Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Pickering Nuclear Plant.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Pickering Nuclear Generating Station]]]] [[File:Eurodif.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Tricastin Nuclear Power Center|Tricastin Nuclear Power Station]]]] [[File:Chinon nuclear power plant.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Chinon Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Centrale-nucleaire-Bugey.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Bugey Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Ringhals.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Ringhals Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Browns ferry NPP.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:CANDU at Qinshan.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Qinshan Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Centrale nogent.jpeg|thumb|200px|The [[Nogent Nuclear Power Plant]]]] [[File:Gelände des Kernkraftwerk Isar (KKI).jpg|thumb|200px|The [[Isar Nuclear Power Plant]]]] This table lists all currently operational power stations with current net capacity over {{nowrap|1,000 MW}}. Some of these may have reactors under construction, but only current net capacity is listed. Capacity of permanently shut-down reactors is not included, but capacity of long-term shut-down reactors is included. Power stations with past net capacity over {{nowrap|1,000 MW}} and current net capacity under {{nowrap|1,000 MW}} are listed in third table.

revision.text:
'''Parson-naturalists''' were [[Minister (Christianity)|ministers of religion]] who also studied [[natural history]]. The archetypical [[parson-naturalist]] was a [[Priest#Anglican or Episcopalian|priest in the Church of England]] in charge of a country parish, who saw the study of science as an [[Relationship between religion and science|extension of his religious work]]. The philosophy entailed the belief that God, as the Creator of all things, wanted man to understand his Creations and thus to study them through [[scientific technique]]s.Armstrong, 2000. They often collected and preserved natural artefacts such as leaves, flowers, birds' eggs, birds, insects, and small mammals to classify and study. Some wrote books or kept nature diaries. ==Parson-naturalists== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |+ Leading parson-naturalists ! Name !! Dates !! Description !! Known for !! Portrait |- | [[William Turner (naturalist)|Turner, William]]Raven, Charles E. 1947. ''English naturalists from Neckam to Ray: a study of the making of the modern world''. Cambridge. p38 || 1508?–1568 || [[dean (religion)|Dean]] of [[Wells Cathedral]] || [[Herbalism]]
''Libellus de Re Herbaria'' || [[File:William Turner Libellus de Re Herbaria 1538 candido lectori SPD page 02.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Gilbert White|White, Gilbert]]{{DNB Cite|wstitle=White, Gilbert|last=Newton|first=Alfred|authorlink=Alfred Newton|volume=61}} || 1720–1793 || [[Curate]] of [[Selborne]], [[Hampshire]]
[[ornithology]] || ''[[Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne]]'' || [[File:Gilbert White.jpg|75px]]
Probably
not authentic |- | [[John Ray|Ray, John]]{{cite web | url=http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/history/ray.html | title=Biography: John Ray | publisher=UCMP Berkeley | accessdate=31 March 2013}} || 1627–1705 || Father of English [[natural history]];
[[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomy]]; [[empiricism]] || ''[[Historia Plantarum (Ray)|Historia Plantarum]]'' || [[File:John Ray from NPG.jpg|75px]] |- | [[William Derham|Derham, William]]{{cite book | title=Gilbert White. A biography of the author of The Natural History of Selborne | publisher=Century Hutchinson | date=1986 | author=Mabey, Richard | authorlink=Richard Mabey | page=11}} || 1657–1735 || ''Physico-Theology'', ([[Natural theology]]) || Estimated [[speed of sound]]
[[Astronomy]], listed [[nebulae]] || [[File:William Derham.jpg|75px]] |- | [[John Lightfoot (biologist)|Lightfoot, John]]Boulger, George Simonds. [[wikisource:Lightfoot, John (1735-1788) (DNB00)|DNB, 1885-1900, Volume 33: Lightfoot, John]] || 1735–1788 || Botanist
[[Conchologist]] || ''Flora Scotica'' (1789) || [[File:Flora Scotica by The Revd John Lightfoot title page.jpg|75px]] |- | [[John Stevens Henslow|Henslow, John Stevens]]{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JwYFAAAAYAAJ | title=Memoir of the Rev. John Stevens Henslow | publisher=John Van Voorst | author=Jenyns, Leonard | date=1862}} || 1796–1861 || Botanist, [[Geologist]] || Mentor and friend of his pupil [[Charles Darwin]] || [[File:John Stevens Henslow.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Leonard Jenyns|Jenyns, Leonard]]{{cite web|title=The Life of Jenyns |url=http://www.rogerco.freeserve.co.uk/jenyns4.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060205103306/http://www.rogerco.freeserve.co.uk/jenyns4.htm |archivedate=2006-02-05 |df= }} || 1800–1893 || Priest, founder of Bath Natural History
and Antiquarian Field Club || [[Phenology]] and [[meteorology]] observations || |- | [[William Darwin Fox|Fox, William Darwin]]{{cite book | author=Larkum, A.W.D. | date=2009 | title=A Natural Calling: Life, Letters and Diaries of Charles Darwin and William Darwin Fox | publisher=Springer Verlag}} || 1805–1880 || Priest, [[Entomologist]], collector of [[beetles]] || Tutored his second cousin [[Charles Darwin]] in natural history || [[File:William Darwin Fox2.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Henry Baker Tristram|Tristram, Henry Baker]]Armstrong, 2000. p. 6 || 1822–1906 || Biblical scholar, [[Ornithologist]] || Early acceptance of Darwinism,
tried to reconcile it with creation || [[File:HBTristram1908.jpg|75px]] |- | [[John George Wood|Wood, John George]]{{EB1911|wstitle=Wood, John George}} || 1827–1889 || Natural history populariser and lecturer || ''Common Objects of the Country'' || [[File:John George Wood - Project Gutenberg eText 13103.jpg|75px]] |- | [[William Dallinger|Dallinger, William]]{{cite journal | jstor=532058 | title=The Reverend Dr William Henry Dallinger, F.R.S. (1839-1909) | author=Haas, J. W., Jr | journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London |date=January 2000 | volume=54 | issue=1 | pages=53–65 | doi=10.1098/rsnr.2000.0096 | pmid=11624308}} || 1839–1909 || [[Wesleyan Methodist Church (Great Britain)|Methodist]] minister, [[microbiology]] || Research on [[unicellular organism|monads]]
Opposition to [[spontaneous generation]] || |- | [[Spencer Cowper (priest)|Cowper, Spencer]]{{cite journal | jstor=40647193 | title=A Contribution to Meteorology by Spencer Cowper, Dean of Durham 1746-74 |author1=Kenworthy, Joan M |author2=McCollum, Margaret S | journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London |date=March 2009 | volume=63 | issue=1 | pages=57–80 | doi=10.1098/rsnr.2007.0047}} || 1713–1774 || [[Dean of Durham]] 1746–1774 || [[Meteorology]] || [[File:Spencer Cowper, dean of Durham 1746-1774.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Francis Orpen Morris|Morris, Francis Orpen]]Armstrong, 2000. pp. 74–78 || 1810–1893 || Irascible Irish clergyman
Hated [[Darwinism]], fox-hunting
Campaigned for
bird conservation law || ''History of British Birds''
''A Bible Natural History''
''Records of Animal Sagacity and Character''
''Dogs and Their Doings'' || [[File:Francis Orpen Morris.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Andrew Bloxam|Bloxam, Andrew]]{{Cite journal |last=Berkeley |first=M.J. |date=1878 |title=The Rev. Andrew Bloxam: A Memoir |journal=Midland Naturalist |volume=1 |pages=88–90 |author1-link=Miles Joseph Berkeley }} || 1801–1878 || Naturalist on {{HMS|Blonde|1819|6}}
Later priest and naturalist || Recorded and collected Hawaiian birds,
some now extinct
Later particularly known for fungi, ''[[Rubus]]'' and ''[[Rose|Rosa]]'' || [[File:Bloxam Brothers Drawing.jpg|75px]] |- | [[Miles Joseph Berkeley|Berkeley, Miles Joseph]]{{cite book | author = Massee, George | year = 1913 | chapter = [[wikisource:Makers of British botany/Miles Joseph Berkeley 1803—1889|Miles Joseph Berkeley 1803—1889]] | editor = Oliver, Francis Wall | title = Makers of British Botany | publisher = Cambridge University Press | pages = 225–232 | editor-link = Francis Wall Oliver}} || 1803–1889 || Vicar of [[Sibbertoft]] for much of his life
Known as the founder of British [[mycology]] || Account of native British fungi in Sir [[William Jackson Hooker]]'s ''British Flora'' (1836)
''Introduction to Cryptogamic Botany'' (1857)
''Outlines of British Fungology'' (1860) || [[File:Miles Joseph Berkeley00.jpg|75px]] |- | [[William Richardson Linton|Linton, William Richardson]]{{cite journal |last1=Edees |first1=Eric Smoothey |title=Notes on Derbyshire bramble |journal=BSBI Proceedings |date=1963 |volume=5 |pages=13–19 |url=http://archive.bsbi.org.uk/Proc5p13.pdf}} || 1850–1908 || Botanist, Vicar of [[Shirley, Derbyshire]] || Work on brambles of [[Derbyshire]], including ''[[Rubus durescens]]''
''[https://archive.org/details/floraofderbyshir00lint Flora of Derbyshire: Flowering Plants, Higher Cryptogams, Mosses and Hepatics, Characeae]'' || [[File:William Richardson Linton.jpg|75px]] |} ==See also== * [[List of Christian thinkers in science]] * [[Science in the Age of Enlightenment]] == References == {{reflist|26em}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |author=Armstrong, Patrick |title=The English Parson-naturalist: A Companionship Between Science and Religion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hB0hEc4CN3wC |date=2000 |publisher=Gracewing Publishing|isbn=978-0-85244-516-7}} [[Category:Parson-naturalists|*]] [[Category:Lists of people by activity]] [[Category:Natural history]] [[Category:Christian priests]] {{Natural history}}

This is a '''list of rivers in [[Swaziland]]'''. This list is arranged by drainage basin, with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} '''''Millennium Live''''' is a cancelled international [[television special]], which was an unsuccessful attempt to broadcast an international celebration of the beginning of the Year 2000, or the so-called [[Millennium]]. Reports claimed that the show was to have involved broadcasters in up to 130 nations. ''Millennium Live: Humanity's Broadcast'' was going to compete against the ''[[2000 Today]]'' international broadcast that was supported by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in the [[United States]], and led by [[BBC]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].
The programme was called off on 28 December 1999 when its organizers, the Millennium Television Network (MTN), announced that it had failed to obtain sufficient financing for the broadcast. MTN reportedly was not paying production and satellite companies for their services prior to the cancellation before MTN shelved their efforts to establish a global broadcast for the following New Year's Eve.
==History==
The Millennium Television Network (MTN) was formed by [[Live Aid|Live Aid's]] American producer Hal Uplinger to prepare and conduct the broadcast.<ref name="VarNov1999">{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/1999/tv/news/millennium-adds-talent-1117757948/ | work=Variety | title=‘Millennium’ adds talent | date=10 November 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014 }}</ref> A series of Early planning activities among international representatives reportedly occurred in [[Cannes]] in October 1998.<ref name=PAXMay99>{{cite news | url=http://www.everything2000.com/news/news/paxtv.asp | title=Pax TV To Broadcast 24-hour Millennium Show | publisher=Business Wire | date=21 May 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203184329/http://www.everything2000.com/news/news/paxtv.asp | archive-date=3 February 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''Millennium Live'' was planned as a 24- or 25-hour broadcast from 11:00 [[UTC]] 31 December 1999.
Pax TV (now known as [[ION Television]]) of the [[United States]] had the exclusive rights to broadcast the show which they were billed as ''Pax Millennium Live: A New World's Eve''.<ref name=SFC1999>{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Oh-the-Humanity-If-World-Ends-TV-s-Got-It-2887618.php | newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle | title=`Oh, the Humanity' -- If World Ends, TV's Got It | date=29 December 1999 | first=John | last=Carman | accessdate=1 February 2014 }}</ref>
''Millennium Live'' was competing against the [[2000 Today]] international broadcast that was supported by [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] and [[ABC 2000 Today|ABC]] in the [[United States]], and led by [[BBC]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].
Scheduled musical guests included [[Aerosmith]], [[Bee Gees]], [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]], [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]], [[Phil Collins]], [[Destiny's Child]], [[Ricky Martin]], [['N Sync]], [[The Pretenders]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Carlos Santana|Santana]] and [[10,000 Maniacs]].<ref name="VarNov1999" /><ref name=SFC1999 /><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.caller2.com/1999/december/26/today/elaine_l/4059.html | newspaper=Corpus Christi Caller-Times | title=TV rings in New Year | date=26 December 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204113036/http://www.caller2.com/1999/december/26/today/elaine_l/4059.html | archivedate=4 February 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=ChiTribDec1999 /><ref name=VarDOA>{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/1999/tv/news/pax-s-live-for-y2k-doa-1117760327/ | title=Pax’s ‘Live’ for Y2K DOA | first=Michael | last=Schneider | date=28 December 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> [[Bryan Adams]], [[Simply Red]] and the [[Spice Girls]] were also sought as featured artists.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://everything2000.com/news/news/headlinemtn.asp | publisher=PAX TV | title=Headliners Named For MTN Broadcast | date=7 October 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
[[New Year's Eve]] celebrations from various worldwide locations were to have been seen on the show.<ref name=ChiTribDec1999>{{cite news | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-12-26/entertainment/9912260132_1_irving-berlin-times-square-coverage | newspaper=Chicago Tribune | title=Ready To Pop | date=26 December 1999 | first=Allan | last=Johnson | accessdate=1 February 2014 }}</ref> Angelica Castro (Chile), [[Carmen Electra]] (US), Ramzi Malouki (France), and Zam Nkosi (South Africa) were also scheduled as a program hosts for the represented nations.<ref name="VarNov1999" /> The studios of a television special were to have been hosted in [[Los Angeles]] on a set contained in a 90-foot [[geodesic dome]] at [[Manhattan Beach, California|Manhattan Beach]] in the [[United States]].<ref name="VarNov1999" />
The program was cancelled on 28 December 1999 with an announcement that MTN had failed to obtain sufficient financing for the broadcast.<ref name=VarDOA /><ref name=SFC30Dec1999>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1999/12/30/DD85230.DTL |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060910143412/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F1999%2F12%2F30%2FDD85230.DTL |archivedate=10 September 2006 |title=Producers Cancel Global Millennium Telecast |first=John |last=Carman |date=30 December 1999 |accessdate=1 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> MTN reportedly was not paying production and satellite companies for their services prior to the cancellation.<ref name=VarDOA /> Pax aired a series of movies in ''Millennium Live's'' place,<ref name=Var29Dec1999>{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/1999/tv/news/nixed-show-irks-global-b-casters-1117760363/ | title=Nixed show irks global b’casters | date=29 December 1999 | first=Michael | last=Schneider | work=Variety | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> and MTN never materialised it's reported plans to establish a global broadcast for the following New Year's Eve on the real [[Millennium]] (2001).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.satellitetoday.com/publications/via-satellite-magazine/2000/04/10/satellite-televisions-biggest-weekend-live-complex-millennium-networks/ | title=Satellite Television’s Biggest Weekend: Live, Complex Millennium Networks | work=Satellite Today | date=10 April 2000 | accessdate=1 February 2014 }}</ref>
==Broadcasters== The following broadcasters were reported{{where|date=February 2014}} as participants in ''Millennium Live'': Note: [[RAI]] was the only broadcaster that moved to the ''[[2000 Today]]'' broadcast * [[Australia]]: [[Nine Network]]<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Brazil]]: [[Rede Bandeirantes]]<ref name=PRNOct99>{{cite news | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Artists+Confirmed+For+%27Millennium+Live...+Humanity%27s+Broadcast%27.-a056054159 | title=Artists Confirmed For 'Millennium Live... Humanity's Broadcast' | publisher=PR Newswire | date=7 October 1999 | accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> * [[Canada]]: [[M3 (Canadian TV channel)|MuchMoreMusic]]<ref name=Var29Dec1999 /> * [[Chile]]: [[Chilevisión]] * [[Estonia]]: [[TV1 (Estonia)|TV1]] * [[France]]: [[France 2]]<ref name=Var29Dec1999 /> * [[Germany]]: [[Sat.1]]<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Hong Kong]]: [[STAR (Greater China)|STAR TV]], [[Asia Television|ATV]] & [[Television Broadcasts Limited|TVB]] * [[India]]: [[Zee TV]]<ref name=Var29Dec1999 /><ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Italy]]: [[Rai 1]], [[Rai 2]], [[Rai 3]], [[Italia1]], [[Rete 4]], [[Canale5]] * [[Japan]]: Vibe TV (now [[MTV Japan]])<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Mexico]]: [[Televisa]], & [[TV Azteca]] * [[South Africa]]: SABC<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Spain]]: [[Telecinco]]<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[United States]]: [[I (TV network)|Pax]] (now [[Ion Television]])<ref name=PRNOct99 /> * [[Venezuela]]: [[Venevisión]]<ref name=PRNOct99 />
==See also== * ''[[2000 Today]]'' - the successful international television special, which was broadcast in 78 countries (including broadcasters from the cancelled ''Millennium Live'' TV special)

Lacks Facts. Backtracks. Sacks Millennium Quacks to the Max] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070206082015/http://www.egypt2000.com/tdots/head/head2/ Egypt2000.com - The Twelve Dreams of the Sun - Jean-Michel Jarre performance]
